instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Hi. I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that gets only 5v 200mA on all four usb-c ports. Won't power on obviously.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> shows 1.2v no matter which usbc I use. The ports looked funky. I took both out and connected a brand new port. Made no difference.

Diode mode to ground shows 0.331 on PP3V3-G3H

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Diode mode looks good.
Post <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message: It's very hard to get readings from that chip. What tool do you guys use?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Avoid touching pins of such kind of chip!
Use surrounding components as test points.

"<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:10 <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>            0.06v"
Enable signal doesn't come from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode to ground at F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Ah, okay. Very helpful. Thank you.
Did the voltage again with test pins.

<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:1 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VBST</SIGNAL>            5.65v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:2 <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>         4.66v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:3 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_LX</SIGNAL>                1.04v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:4 GND                        
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:5 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_AGND</SIGNAL>            0v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:6
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:7 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_AGND</SIGNAL>            0v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:8 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_BIAS</SIGNAL>            4.65v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:9 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB</SIGNAL>                0.33v
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:10 <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>            4.95v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U6903</CHIP>:10 <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>            4.95v"
So enable signal is present indeed.
Be sure to post accurate information ALWAYS.

Check <RESISTOR>R6908</RESISTOR> and feedback resistors <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13.
If good, change <CAPACITOR>C6907</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Indeed, you are right. Apologies.

When checking the resistors in diode mode, should I use the test pads also?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Must check the resistors in ohm scale.
Onboard measurments will not match the exact value; remove and check them out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
Ah okay.

These are the measurements I got from the pads.

<RESISTOR>R6908</RESISTOR>:1 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VBST_R</SIGNAL>             5.67v
<RESISTOR>R6908</RESISTOR>:2 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VBST</SIGNAL>             5.67v
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VBST</SIGNAL> diode mode             0.579
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VBST_R</SIGNAL> diode mode         0.579

<RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>:1 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB</SIGNAL>                0.33v
<RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>:2 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB_R</SIGNAL>                0.94v
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB</SIGNAL> diode mode             0.560
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB_R</SIGNAL> diode mode             0.333

<RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>:1 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB</SIGNAL>                0.33v
<RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>:2 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB_RC</SIGNAL>            0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB_RC</SIGNAL> diode mode        0.494

<RESISTOR>R6912</RESISTOR>:1 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_REG_R</SIGNAL>            0.33v
<RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>:2 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB_R</SIGNAL>                0.94v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_REG_R</SIGNAL>     diode mode        0.328

<RESISTOR>R6913</RESISTOR>:1 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB_RC</SIGNAL>            0v
<RESISTOR>R6913</RESISTOR>:2 <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_AGND</SIGNAL>            0v
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_AGND</SIGNAL> diode mode            0.0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 5V on charger, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1v
threads.message:
I said to check the resistors value in ohm scale.
Nothing to check on the board to ground.
"remove and check them out."
